comments.commentBody:
The "clear answer in 2016", Mr. Walker? Really? Do they teach basic math in your state sir? HRC received 3 million more votes than Mr. Trump.

The only thing more repulsive than a self-confident conservative and his/her hateful "I got mine, you get yours" politics, is one who claims to speak on behalf of all Americans.

You under-estimate the degree to which we hate this President; to the extent that you support and normalize his anti-Presidential behavior, we hate you too.

I wonder if (so-called) Governor Walker would agree that all elected and appointed public officials should undergo tests for drug use.  Those individual are also "getting public assistance", because their pay checks come from Wisconsin taxpayers.  If not, he should get off his high horse and discuss publicly what his real agenda is:  undermining government's proper role at every opportunity.  I also wonder if Walker would agree that Republicans should actually face ALL the voters, rather than some gerrymandered subset.

Funny, Republicans are very MUCH about getting government into people's live.  OTHER people's lives.  Other people's bedrooms and wombs.  They want all control over others, no control over themselves.

.......and in order archive my goal, of returning decisions to the states, I am prepared to overlook the lies being told by this administration, turn a blind eye to Russian interference in the election and ignore the racist/narcissist tendencies of POTUS, because I'm a constitution loving Patriot!
Maybe such goals should be archived.
This is an opinion piece. Walker's opinion is nasty, but it is his. The NYT must print all opinions. Otherwise, we sink to the same level as Walker.
Love, love, love your comment!
You are an honorable and rational Republican, Sir. If only there were more in your party as thoughtful as you are!
But it IS about punishment, the aim of true Puritans.

I love how Walker draws a distinction between protestors and liberals and "taxpayers" in his construction. His protestors were mostly union members with jobs - and a lot of the same people who supported Trump apparently. I'm going to bet they paid their taxes. Liberal old me pays more taxes than the majority of the country - frpm what records we could obtain, I pay more taxes than the President.

It's shoddy to see this "us and them" mentality coming from public officials regarding citizens. I disliked the Tea Party and found their antics obnoxious and hostile. But I remember Obama calling them "folks." And the only time I remember hearing the "they're being paid" rhetoric about protestors was when those aggressive Republican men marched into the recount offices in Florida during Bush-Gore. Nowadays Republican leaders, thanks to Trump, seem to think they can talk about liberal citizens that disagree with them like dirt - just dismiss our opinions as those of crybabies, paid protestors, and fake news. That's as big a betrayal of America as palling around with Putin.

I don't think the teachers unions supported Walker or Trump for record. The Demonstrators in Madison at the time of Act 10 were largely teachers and other government workers who did not support the idea of paying for some of their salaries for benefits.  Look who was protesting Devos hearings in the Senate. The Democratic party gets most of its funding from unions especially public sector unions. They tried to stop Walker and failed.

Ann:  the republicans will only be able to dismiss the protesting left until the next election.  if the left comes out with energy and conviction, the right won't (can't) match it-- repealing the AFA isn't as passionate a matter as keeping the insurance that keeps loved ones alive...the GOP will be going down with the Trump ship in short order.
"Right to work" Ie anti-union States have lower wages, lower standards of living and more poverty.

Gov. Walker, like most of the Republican world, seems to be looking at data from a special perspective. Yes, Wisconsin is doing well, but so is neighbor Minnesota where they still have collective bargaining, and they raised taxes to balance the budget. California is also outperforming Wisconsin taking the same route as Minnesota. I think the best illustration of Gov. Walker's vision can be found in Kansas. Do we really want this country to have the Kansas solution?  It is so bad there that the Republican dominated legislature is likely to raise taxes over Gov. Brownback's veto. After years of tax cuts for business (the wealthy) and deficit budgets based on fantasy growth figures which required depleting state reserves, pension funds, salary reductions, massive teacher shortages, and rotting highways, Kansans are realizing the truth. Their suffering has been for naught because there was no light at the end of the tunnel. Our country and each state is a community where we all live together, work together and succeed together. Remember, this country revolted against the King based on the idea of an equal community. In a very real sense today's Republican's are the Tories of the 18th century, taxing the poor and giving the revenue to the rich.

Unclebugs, thanks for your comment. In some ways, Wisconsin is already seeing some of the same issues as Kansas. Our roads are in disrepair. Our teachers have been so badly treated (demonized and lost collective bargaining rights) that we now have a teacher shortage that has led the Dept. of Ed. to look into changing certification so that teachers get a Pre-K through 12 licensure so that we can put teachers in our schools. Our excellent University of Wisconsin system has slipped in national ratings due to cut funding, tuition freezes, and exiting faculty (again, low morale), who take their research funding with them. Programs that study climate change, green farming practices, and protections of our natural resources have seen cuts. Yet, the state gives money to millionaires to build a new basketball arena and votes themselves a 31% per diem increase. Oh, yes, but he's getting people back to work by making them pee in a cup. Our "big and bold" governor, who tells Republicans to "face the voters" and "get to work" doesn't practice what he preaches. His public appearances are by invitation only, and most of his constituents find out he's been in town only after the fact.
Exactly each state gets the policies that their citizens want and can make work.  And the poor today don't get taxed much, they have no money.

Yes, Unclebugs is right and Kansas is the perfect example of what NOT to do. Minnesota is actually doing far better than Wisconsin. We'll see what happens now in Iowa after the legislature voted to get rid of collective bargaining.

The most sensible of solutions. Cities have the means to defend and feed themselves, thanks to technology, zero percent of which has come about due to "rural" people. Rural used to mean part of an agricultural community. Now it means a wasteland of real guns and fake bibles.

Why are concerned citizens "paid protesters" when they confront their own Republican congressional representatives about their positions on issues important to them, but "patriots" when they show up at town halls outside their voting districts in funny three-cornered hats and scream about gun rights?
And how about drug-testing everyone with tax-deductible employer-sponsored health insurance or who claim a mortgage-interest deduction? Those are much larger forms of "public assistance" than either TANF or SSI.
Hubert Humphrey must be smiling...!
Thank you for this excellent counter-argument.

Well, it's not a nation anymore when half of it support and condone the vilification and stigmatization of the other half. I support the establishment of a new Maritimerica, on the coasts. The rest can go devise any kind of bible-gun utopia they can dream up, on their own.
No more RFD ( rural free delivery)!
Soros funded rent-a-mobs? Some people will believe anything!

Wonder if conspiring with another country to use its illegally acquired information to secure a desired outcome of a national election, thus undermining the most important foundation block of our democracy, would be proscribed by the Constitution at Art. III; Sec.3?
Maybe we the people could ask this so-called president, Benedict Donald.

Well, I would have given Republicans a lot more credit if they'd actually had a plan ready to go the second they got their opportunity to have their dream of taking away health insurance from millions of newly protected people come true. Now they just look like a bunch of incompetent bozos who whip up and exploit the public's anger to get elected but don't have a plan beyond that. Except to coast like fat cats and hope that the wealthy will give them a big private sector job once they hand out the 13% tax cuts for them, 2% for the middle class. Yeah, they're pretty lame. Maybe you want to take some of that sweet Soros money and come protest with us.

Sometimes it's better to be lucky than good and that's what I was at the end with the crossings of GINUP (never heard that) and SGTS and especially SPORCLE and NECCO. I kind of like the sound of SPORCLENECCO but I guess it's not likely to replace Natick.

Beyond that a very nice puzzle. A few early gimmes allowed me to fill in a lot of it pretty quickly (for a Saturday) but other areas took considerable work. Nice long downs (well, if I'd heard of the actress) and some other lively entries as well. Completely blanked on the Cotillard film on first pass but it dawned on me shortly thereafter. Similarly with SHIRLEYCHISHOLM.

TAGS without a dog seemed a little off for that clue, but it wasn't a problem. That and PIAF reminded me of a couple of memorable scenes from 'Saving Private Ryan.' Neat to see NHRA after our extended discussion of drag racing yesterday.

Links: Edith PIAF (of course):

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kFzViYkZAz4

And (speaking of crossings) in this brief clip Jimmy Cagney solves the puzzle and really struggles with 26a.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XK0mjeIky0Y

Je ne regrette rien.
Yeah, Jesus said much earlier.

The Protesters are taxpayers too.  We are protesting the priorities of how our money is spent.  Nationally we outnumber conservatives, but because of how districts are carved up and the over representation of small population states, the GOP has more power than it really represents.  We want health care, a clean environment, a fair wage, affordable housing, a more peaceful approach to the world, women's rights to choose, equal rights for minority races, religions and sexual orientations....the equality that this country is supposed to be about.  The GOP position especially under this president is to undermine our clean air, water, soil to allow business to dump anything anywhere again, to rip health care away from millions who can't afford it because good jobs have been replaced with ones that cannot support a living, our taxes are being squandered on useless wars, overdone security, a stupid wall (if it ever happens), an assault on minorities, a stealing of public lands to be exploited for fossil fuels-something we should be trying to move away from.  The Protesters are telling you loud and clear that standing firm is not what many of your constituents want, not even what some may have voted for you want.  States rights is a tool of divisiveness. As someone who has lived all over the country, I don't want to feel like I'm in a foreign country when I go to another state.  States rights should not trump the unity of the United States.  We should all have the same rights.

I have a suspicion Mary that conservative taxpayers outnumber liberal taxpayers.

Also, to be honest, some communities like blacks of Hispanics or Muslims do not share your liberal values. For instance abortion is banned or restricted in most of Latin America. Christianity in Africa is more conservative than Christianity in America. Gays in Islamic countries have far fewer rights, if any, than gays in America.

But because they are terrified of Republicans, these three communities tend to vote Democratic. They vote the same way you do but their values are not the same as yours.

How will they enter the national dialogue? Not through you. And not through the Republicans. They are little more than pawns.

That's an incredibly stereotypical line of reasoning...plus the lack of freedoms and hyper conservativism in Islamic countries is certainly not something this country is striving for.  And the line about liberal taxpayers being outnumbered is hogwash - you are assuming Democrats are mostly on the dole and so are their voters with that ridiculous comment.  I would warrant there's plenty of each on both sides, but densely populated areas with varied information outlets and familiarity with the "other" (minorities religious, racial, or gender) vote overwhelmingly Democratic, (and Hillary got 3 million more VOTES I will remind you) while rural low information areas with a pretty homogenous population (white/Christian) with little familiarity of the "other" they've been taught to fear vote GOP. I assure you I'm a taxpayer at nearly 40% of my income and I don't like where Trump plans to spend MY hard earned dollars at all.

I prefer to give to organizations here in Chicago which help the homeless and hungry. When I go downtown, I can be asked literally dozens of times for money just walking around. Rather than hand out a dollar here and there I simply don't  approach it this way (though on occasion - I once gave $40 dollars - all I had on me - to a mother begging on a bitterly cold evening). I agree that we should help, but how to be most effective is also a question.

The Pope is right. Giving money directly to the homeless is the fastest way to alleviate suffering. Giving money to organizations that help the homeless may not in fact do anything for individual homeless people. Many hopeless are so afraid of rape or exploitation at shelters that they won't even go to them. Many shelter staff take donations, and the homeless never see them. These staff feel it is their "right" since they are often poorly compensated for what they do.

That said, male panhandlers make a lot more money from random charity than female panhandlers do. If you are going to give money on the street, make sure you also give to females. As someone who was homeless (and female) I know this firsthand.

If you want to really help individual homeless people, consider giving 20.00 gift cards to a general store like Target, and insist that the shelter you give them to has each homeless resident sign off on having received them. This will minimize the chances of the money being spent on alcohol or drugs, and still allow each homeless person some choice to buy what he or she needs most.

Arduin, a Prince of a guy, and let us hold on to the Policy of Fear, State first, People next, and the Nation will be buying guns like lollipops. Donald Duck will be quacking that pollution is caused by trees; a nation of hypocritical preachers with the brains of pterodactyls and politicians who would sell their daughters for a vote, and let us not forget Mr. Reagan who once visited Mississippi where three civil rights workers were lynched. He declared that he stood for States' Rights, and every good ol'boy from Tallahassee to Kalamazoo got the message.

Now when it comes to sessions with Jeff Sessions, well now, he is quite sure, even confident although he cannot quite remember, that there has been no hanky pank playing on his part with Russia. If we could just give the new Attorney General a moment to breathe, let's see some phone logs maintained by his office and expect to hear that this is not the policy of his Office. No, Sir.
Stand strong Democrats and Wisconsiites. This Walker who represents the interests of the wealthy must be opposed.

A typical response from the paranoid Left. "Republicans stand for the rich". They think Trump ,Romney, and Bush only wanted to help those in the .3% bracket. How superficial and naive. Behind what the Libs see as a tilt toward a privileged class, are men and women who understand the imbalance of our economic strata, while creating more opportunities for valid work, not redistribution by the State or Federal governments. How are you so opposed to that?
